author: Alan Mitchell
title: Payroll tax surfaces as the next GST
text:
Ged Kearney and Martin Parkinson discuss tax reform. Louie Douvis by Alan Mitchell Business is demanding reform while ACTU president Ged Kearney wants an expanded payroll tax. Joe Hockey must be wondering how politics in a republic could possibly be as good as this.
Kearney's argument at Wednesday's National Reform Summit , was that an expanded and more efficient payroll tax would be better than an increase in the GST.
Payroll tax, she argued, was paid by employers and was levied for those actually earning wages.
The former Treasury secretary, Martin Parkinson, corrected Kearney's economics . A payroll tax with no concessions, he said, is identical to a GST.
But if Kearney's argument was weak on the economic fine detail, it was stronger on the politics of tax reform.
The public is certain it pays the GST, but it thinks employers carry the burden of payroll tax. It also thinks company tax falls entirely on business, and it is likely to be sceptical of Parkinson's argument that half the burden of the tax falls on workers.
So, if business is to get a cut in company tax, it might be politically smart to ask businesses to contribute to the cost by paying more payroll tax.
The Treasurer's thoughts probably have been heading in that direction anyway.
 Small GST rise not enough
As commentators have noted, the 5 percentage point increase in the GST rate proposed by the NSW government would not raise enough revenue to solve the fiscal problems facing the federal and state governments.
Hockey will want the states to increase their other efficient taxes to raise more money and payroll tax is the most obvious candidate.
In a speech on tax reform last Monday, Hockey emphasised what he said was the sixth principle of the government's tax reform: that "the revenue-raising capacity of each tier of government should be aligned to responsibilities of funding and service delivery".
Even if he doesn't want to be taken literally, it seems pretty clear that he does want good deal more from the states than Mike Baird's proposed increase in the GST.
The states are estimated to need an extra $20 billion a year by 2020 to make up for reduced growth of federal health grants. The federal government needs to close the budget deficit, compensate low income households for the increase in their living costs, and finance a cut in company and personal income tax.
The estimated $36 billion increase in the GST under the Baird plan is not going to be anything like enough.
Bigger rise would be unpopular
One option would be a bigger increase in the GST, but that does not seem politically feasible.
An efficient (that is, concession free) payroll tax in addition to the 5 percentage point GST rise would make more political sense.
Despite claims to the contrary, payroll tax is inherently efficient and, under certain assumptions, is identical to a consumption tax.
People forget that payroll tax was transferred to the states by the McMahon government in the early 1970s as an efficient growth tax.
Vote buying by the premiers and interstate tax competition has seen the payroll tax base eroded to an inefficient shadow of its former self.
If the politicians and business cannot manage the increase in GST and payroll tax required for reform, land tax could make up the difference.
Land tax is more efficient than either the GST or payroll tax and, if it were confined to expensive properties, it would allow the nation's business leaders to make an additional direct financial contribution to economic reform.
